answers.author: Derek Johnson
answers.text:
Tom,
The City of Dublin, Ohio recently introduced six economic development agreements to their city council in an effort to retain a telecommunications company that was considering moving out of Ohio (and taking over 700 local jobs with it). 
http://icma.org/en/Article/100903/Economic_Development_Agreements_Attracting_Job_Growth
Building on a policy the month prior approving $10 million in redeemable tax credits over ten years, the proposed EDA's would provide additional incentives to Alcatel-Lucent.
In addition, the city also has proposals in place to provide incentives for other businesses and organizations, like the expansion of Nationwide Children's Hospital facilities within Dublin and tax credits for several other businesses looking to create jobs locally.
It may be helpful to contact Dublin officials to ask for more detailed documents relating to their strategy and how it could be implemented in your municipality:
Contact: Sue Burness at 614.327.1274 | sburness@dublin.oh.us | Twitter: @sueburness
In addition, ICMA's Business Retention Topic Page contains a whole host of resources that provide advice and guidelines on how to work with, attract and keep companies doing business in your area:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/31/Business_Retention#Tab=Overview
Please take a good look there. I'm sure you'll find something helpful if you do. Good luck!
Derek Johnson

author: Thomas Ryff
text:
I would like to know if there are any Cities that have developed a proactive partnership with local business in an effort to increase overall sales within their community. I realize that various Chambers of Commerce, Convention and Tourism Bureau's exist. I'm primarily interested in Cities that are actually partnering with local business - for example, placing actual business links on municipal web-sites etc.
In short, expanding the role of city government, to assist with increased business/sales. New approaches ideas would be appreciated.
title: Municipal Gov't Partnering with Local Business
